metadata.title: COVID-19 in China: Risk Factors and R0 Revisited

abstract.text: The COVID-19 epidemic had spread rapidly through China and subsequently has proliferated 32 globally leading to a pandemic situation around the globe. Human-to-human transmissions, 33 as well as asymptomatic transmissions of the infection, have been confirmed. As of April 3 rd, 34 public health crisis in China due to COVID-19 is potentially under control. We compiled a 35 daily dataset of case counts, mortality, recovery, temperature, population density, and 36 demographic information for each prefecture during the period of January 11 to April 07, 37 2020 (excluding Wuhan from our analysis due to missing data). Understanding the 38 characteristics of spatiotemporal clustering of the COVID-19 epidemic and R0 is critical in 39 effectively preventing and controlling the ongoing global pandemic. The prefectures were 40 grouped based on several relevant features using unsupervised machine learning 41 techniques. We performed a computational analysis utilizing the reported cases in China to 42 estimate the revised R0 among different regions for prevention planning in an ongoing global 43 pandemic. Finally, our results indicate that the impact of temperature and demographic 44 (different age group percentage compared to the total population) factors on virus 45 transmission may be characterized using a stochastic transmission model. Such predictions 46 will help prioritize segments of a given community/ region for action and provide a visual aid 47

body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 22, 2020 . . https://doi.org/10.1101 INTRODUCTION 64 The world is facing an unprecedented pandemic of a virus that originated in 65 Wuhan, China. As such, the virus has been declared a global public health emergency by the Reaction (RT-PCR) tests available globally.(7) COVID-19 has a clinically milder presentation 85 and lower case fatality ratio (CFR) when compared to SARS and MERS (8) and hence, there 86 seems to be an increased risk of asymptomatic or pre-clinically diagnosed individuals 87 spreading the disease (9).
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: With the current state of globalization and increased interconnectedness of the world, the risk 90 of infectious disease spread has increased. A revised estimation of R0 based on some potential 91 risk factors is one of the powerful tools for assessing an epidemic's ability to spread (10, 11).

They provide vital information regarding where resources for containment and treatment 93 should be targeted. Additionally, the case definition of COVID-19 has been updated by the 94 Chinese authorities to now include those who present clinically with evidence of radiographic 95 changes on CT scans of the lungs. Infection rate and mortality are higher among male compare 96 with female (12). The mortality rate is higher among the older age groups (12). Population 97 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. (which was not certified by peer review)
The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 22, 2020 . . https://doi.org/10.1101 4 density might be one of the potential risk factors in the spread of COVID-19 infections (13).
Control effort proved one of the keys to prevent and contain the spatial spread (14). The role 99 of temperature in the spread of COVID-19 has been studied (15-22) and debated among 100 policymakers.

A revised estimation based on the geographic distribution of population density, age group, 103 gender, temperature, morbidity, mortality, and recovery rate from COVID-19 on a contained 104 epidemic country is necessary in order to accurately predict the spatial spread of the virus and 105 identify the risk factors for targeted control. Our study models the spread of COVID-19 among 106 three regions in China, where the regions are not clustered geographically; rather they are 107 intelligently grouped or clustered based on several relevant features (mentioned above) through 108 application of unsupervised machine learning techniques. Thus, it will provide more accurate 109 findings regarding where public health measures should be targeted. body_text.text: The temporal resolution is 6-hour (0000, 0600, 1200, and 1800 UTC) with a spatial resolution 165 of 2.5-degree.

Google earth engine platform was used to download the required data following a three-step 168 process: selection of required data, extraction to geographical location, and export to google (Table 1 , Supplement) and identified three separate regions within mainland China. Now, 182 different sets of features (i.e., criteria used for clustering) may result in different outputs (i.e., 183 different regional grouping). To analyse this, we applied our clustering algorithm on four 184 different sets of features/criteria that include incidence, recovery rate, mortality rate, male-185 female ratio, age group ratio, minimum, mean and maximum temperature in each prefecture.

body_text.text: All analysis was conducted using the R language (version 3.6.3). We adopted and modified 232 the code provided by Kucharski et al. (29) . For reading and manipulating data we used 233 readxl, magrittr, tidyverse, tidyr,DMwr and plyr R packages in addition to pre-installed 234 packages. For processing dates we used R package lubridate. body_text.text: As of April 7, 2020, total cases reported in China were 83,845 (including Wuhan). The 264 average of daily mean temperature ranged from -25.0560 °C to 21.3948 °C.

Three regions in different clustering 267 All four clustering (Table 1) (Table 1 & Supplement Table 1 ). From the PCA analysis (Figure 2 supplement) , it 271 is evident that temperature profile played a significant role, and it is easily noticeable that the 272 increase in temperature increases the R0 value. considers population profile in more detail than other clustering, has played a role here. As it 278 turns out, the ratio of aged population is markedly higher in these two prefectures which 279 essentially put these into the immediate higher R0 region. In the same context, we also notice 280 another apparently anomalous prefecture (i.e., Turfan) at the north-western region, which is 281 light green (medium R0) in Clustering D as opposed to being green (low R0) in other 282 clustering A and C. The analysis shows that the aged population group is not prominent in 283 Turfan; however, further analysis reveals that the sufficiently lower temperature therein has 284 played its part and overshadowed the effect of the aged population. Thus, it seems that we 285 can give higher rank to temperatures in terms of contribution towards transmission than 286 population age. 287 288 289 Region 3 has been identified to be the highest transmission region (among the three) CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

body_text.text: This is the first study to determine the impact of temperature and other potential risk factors 331 through a clustering exercise and to estimate the revised R0 of COVID-19 in different regions 332 in China. We have applied the clustering algorithms using different combination of relevant 333 features to ensure a confident and coherent analysis. Our results strongly indicated that R0 334 may be affected (i.e., worsen) by higher temperature, and the prefectures having older 335 population likely favoured its transmission.

Clustering E is based on temperature profile only and it clearly suggested that higher 338 temperature produced higher R0. This is a unique finding in itself as the role of temperature in 339 the spread of COVID-19 has been studied (15-22) and the predominant prediction was mostly 340 the opposite; evidence from published studies documented negative associations between 341 increasing temperature and 17, 22) .

Also, population turned out to be an important discriminant feature in clustering, and from 344 the results it can be inferred that higher fraction of aged population is a risk factor and 345 contributes to higher R0. While identifying region 3, temperature was the most contributing 346 factor following the demographic factor. Region 3 (exhibiting the highest R0) is the warm 347 region where average of the daily mean temperature is around 8.57 0 C whereas Region 1 and 348 Region 2 has this value below 0 0 C.

We estimated that the mean R0 for the COVID-19 ranges from 1.58 to 2.24 (Table 2 ) and is 351 significantly larger than 1 and is consistent with the WHO's estimation for the human-to-352 human (direct) transmission ranged from 1.4 to 2.5 (33). On the other hand, most of the 353 predicted mean R0 ranging from 2 to 5, and is largely inconsistent with our results (11). The 354 reason might be that active surveillance, contact tracing, quarantine, and early strong social CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 22, 2020 . . https://doi.org/10.1101 scale. However, the association between COVID-19 and temperature was not consistent and 364 changes in temperature showed no significant correlation with cases transmitted, deaths or 365 recovered (16). Our findings at the prefecture level on the impact of temperature conditions 366 over the transmission of COVID-19 are not consistent with other published studies (35, 36) . 367 However, our results are consistent with Luo et al., 2020 (37) , which reported that the 368 changes in temperature as spring and summer months might not lead to decline of confirmed 369 case counts without the implementation of extensive public health interventions.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: The longer the study period, the more stable the model results are expected to be. The most important environmental implication proved temperature is a critical factor for 379 COVID-19 transmission, which also deserve to be better studied in other regions during this 380 pandemic (17).

This study has several limitations, most notably the fact that these analyses were based on 383 routinely collected data during pandemic with the potential for both over and under reporting 384 of COVID-19 cases. Secular changes in reporting could have biased incidence estimates and 385 errors could have been introduced as data were aggregated at higher levels of the health

body_text.text: In conclusions, our study does not support that high temperature can reduce the transmission 399 of COVID-19 and it will be premature to count on warmer weather to control COVID-19 400 (20). A weather with high temperature favors the transmission (17). There were spatial 401 heterogeneities in COVID-19 occurrence, which could be attributed to temperature. body_text.text: If any prefecture has a significant number of an older population group, that prefecture should be considered as high risk; AGR has been computed for three groups, namely, AGR<15 (age below 15), AGR15-64, (age within the range 15-64) and AGR>64 (age over 64).

FIGREF2.text: Health Organization (WHO). The virus is of the genus betacoronavirus which are 67 zoonotically transmitted enveloped RNA viruses (1). Certain strains of Coronavirus are known 68 to cause infections in humans and have led to previous epidemics, such as severe acute 69 respiratory syndrome (SARS) and Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) (2). A new strain 70 of Coronavirus called the COVID-19 has led to a global epidemic since its emergence in 71 Wuhan, China (3). As of May 17, 2020, this disruptive pandemic has been spread among 180 72 countries and infected >4.6 million individuals and caused >0.31 million deaths since the onset 73 of the epidemic. Nearly 0.084 million cases were diagnosed in mainland China (4, 5). The 74 epidemic in China is now under control. 75 76 Initial efforts to stall transmission of the COVID-19 by the Chinese authorities included the 77 closure of the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market which was considered to be the focal point 78 of the outbreak (6). However, in spite of such strong intervention attempts, the rapid spread of 79 the virus could not be prevented. Apart from measures to prevent exposure to the source, 80 diagnostic recognition of the virus is an essential part of preventing efforts to prevent 81 transmission. Diagnostic tests for COVID-19 were developed after isolation of the virus from 82 lower respiratory tract specimens and blood serum (7). Scientists in China provided the genetic 83 sequence of COVID-19 to the WHO, which has in turn, made Real-Time Polymerase Chain 84

FIGREF5.text: for each city were obtained from the National Bureau of Statistics of 156 China (http://www.stats.gov.cn/).

FIGREF7.text: 169 drive. Data selection parameters include, dataset identifier (NCEP_RE/surface_temp), 170 geographical location (China prefecture level), and date (2019-12-01 -2020-04-07). To get the 171 temperature data for each prefecture, ee.Reducer.first() function is used to get the first (or only) 172 value of temperature. Finally, the extracted dataset is exported to the google drive as a CSV 173 file. The temperature dataset consists of four observations per day and is used to obtain 174 minimum, maximum, and mean temperatures.

FIGREF8.text: China into three different regions applying a carefully designed clustering exercise 178 as described below. The full analysis pipeline is illustrated in Figure 1 Supplement. Initially, 179 all the prefectures that reported zero cases were excluded from the analysis. Then we applied 180 an unsupervised clustering algorithm, namely, K-means algorithm, based on several features 181

FIGREF9.text: ). For visualization purposes, Principal Component Analysis (PCA) has been 188 performed to reduce the dimensions of the feature set to two dimensions (Figure 2 and 3, 189 supplement).

FIGREF11.text: all the prefectures into three different regions, a stochastic transmission 204 dynamic model to estimate R0 for each region was fit. The daily incidence, recovery, and 205 mortality of each region were fitted in the model. For estimating R0 of a region, we 206 considered the daily confirmed incidences for all the prefectures of that region. The same 207 procedure is applied for recovery and mortality. 208 209 We divided the population into three different compartments, namely, susceptible, infected 210 and removed (SIR model (28), i.e., isolated, recovered, dead, or otherwise no longer 211 infectious). The rate of change from susceptible to infected is termed as the rate of 212 transmission. Similarly, the rate of change from infected to removed is termed as the removal 213 rate. Following the work of Kucharski et al. (29), in our model, we have assumed that the 214 delay distribution from the onset to isolation follows the well-known Erlang distribution with 215 a mean of 2.9 days and a standard deviation of 2.1 days (30). So the removal rate is assumed 216 to be 0.34 (1/2.9) (31, 32). Transmission is modelled as a stochastic random walk process and 217 sequential Monte Carlo simulation is used to infer the transmission rate over time, resulting 218 number of cases, and the time varying basic reproduction number (Rt). Sequential Monte 219

FIGREF19.text: 355distancing efforts contributed to stop transmission of the virus and significantly decreased the 356 effective reproduction number of COVID-19 in China (10). Published studies also suggest 357 that the first lockdown resulted in a 65% decrease of the reproduction factor R0 and the 358 second, stricter wave of measures eventually managed to bring it to close to 0 (34).

FIGREF20.text: can influence COVID-19 transmission, including environmental variables, 361 population density, and strong public health infrastructures (35). The previous studies have 362 seldom analyzed the effects of temperature on the development of COVID-19 in a large 363 .

FIGREF21.text: Temperature may even have no role in transmission since winter is over and temperature 373 started increasing and cases are increasing in warm areas. Control effort, health behavior, 374 social distance has a very big role in R0 estimation and can inform public health officials and 375 decision makers about where to improve the allocation of resources, testing sites; also, where 376 to implement stricter quarantines and travel bans (38).

FIGREF23.text: 386 information system. Data accuracy and completeness were not systematically assessed. Some 387 cases might be detected based on clinical signs and symptoms, with the potential for 388 misclassification (39). Testing systems have also limited sensitivity and specificity and are 389 particularly likely to misclassify individuals. Parts of China were forced to shut down with 390 restrictions on the population movement. These intervention measures are expected to also 391 have an important impact on the associations between meteorological factors and the 392 transmission of the virus. Additional climatic factors, socio-economic development, 393 population mobility, population immunity, social distancing, health behavior changes, and 394 urbanization, presumably affected the dynamics of the COVID-19 epidemic in China, but we 395 cannot consider every factor in this study. The observed associations between temperature, 396 demographic factors and estimated Ro were ecologic and not at the level of individuals.

TABREF0.text: In this study, 31 provinces of Mainland China were taken into consideration, including 367 county-level administrative areas. The number of daily confirmed, cured, and death of COVID-19 cases were collected from the National Health Commission of the People's Republic of China (http://www.nhc.gov.cn/) and the provincial health commissions.COVID-19 that started to spread from Wuhan in the mainland of China is a notifiable disease collection) tied to add the daily reported cases in China's Infectious Disease Information System (IDIS). IDIS system recorded all cases with identification numbers, to avoid data duplication. All data contained information about morbidity, mortality, and recovery from COVID-19 case records in the IDIS through the end of April 3, 2020, were extracted. IDIS system categorized all the confirmed cases as suspected, clinically diagnosed (Hubei Province only), or asymptomatic. Confirmed cases were diagnosed by testing the viral nucleic acid in throat swabs specimens (some samples tested retrospectively) (23). Suspected cases were diagnosed based on the clinical symptoms and exposure and were classified as clinically 148 diagnosed cases. Clinically diagnosed cases include suspicious cases with lung imaging features consistent with coronavirus pneumonia. The positive viral nucleic acid test is used to

TABREF1.text: The K-means clustering algorithm (with default parameters) was used to do the clustering 196 (24)(25, 26). In our dataset, there are 302 prefectures with at least one incidence. However, we have population and temperature data was available, for 298 and 296 prefectures, respectively. That is why 298 prefectures were considered for clustering B. On the other 199 hand, 296 prefectures were considered for all other clusters. Notably, Wuhan was excluded from the analysis, because data for early days of transmission for Wuhan is not available
